周三，随着新法律生效，要求仅使用国际计算年龄的方法取代了该国的传统方法，韩国人年轻了一两岁。

根据韩国人日常生活中最常用的年龄系统，人们在出生时被视为一岁，并在每年的1月1日增加一岁。

自20世纪60年代初以来，该国一直采用国际标准，在医疗和法律文件中从出生时的零开始计算，并在每个生日时加一年。但许多韩国人继续使用传统方法做其他事情。

12月，韩国通过法律废除传统方法，全面采用国际标准。

政府法制部长官李完圭在周一的新闻发布会上表示：“我们预计，因如何计算年龄而引发的法律纠纷、投诉和社会混乱将大大减少。”

根据 2022 年 9 月进行的一项政府调查，86% 的韩国人表示，新法律生效后，他们将在日常生活中使用国际时代。

“我明年就要满 30 岁了（按照韩国传统的年龄制度），但现在我有了更多的时间，我喜欢它，”首尔 27 岁的办公室职员 Choi Hyun-ji 说。

“感觉自己变年轻了真是太好了，”崔补充道。

韩国在征兵、入学以及计算饮酒和吸烟的法定年龄方面存在另一种年龄制度：一个人的年龄从出生时的零开始计算，并在 1 月 1 日加一岁。官员表示，这种方法将保留到韩国。暂且。

周三，一名男子在斯德哥尔摩中央清真寺外撕毁并焚烧了一本《古兰经》，在瑞典警方批准举行抗议活动后，瑞典正在争取加入北约，这一事件有可能激怒土耳其。

警方随后指控该男子煽动反种族或民族团体。

瑞典发生的一系列反对伊斯兰教和争取库尔德人权利的示威活动冒犯了安卡拉，瑞典需要获得安卡拉的支持才能加入北大西洋公约组织。

去年俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后，瑞典寻求加入北约。但联盟成员国土耳其推迟了这一进程，指责瑞典窝藏其认为是恐怖分子的人，并要求引渡他们。

土耳其外交部长哈坎·菲丹在推特上谴责了这一行为，并补充说，以言论自由的名义允许反伊斯兰抗议活动是不可接受的。

大约 200 名旁观者目睹了两名组织者中的一名抗议者撕毁了一本《古兰经》，并用它擦拭鞋子，然后将培根放入其中并点燃了这本书，而另一名抗议者则对着扩音器讲话。

一些在场的人用阿拉伯语高喊“真主伟大”，抗议焚烧行为，一名男子试图扔石头，但被警方拘留。

当圣书着火时，示威活动的一名支持者高喊“让它燃烧吧”。

焚烧事件发生后，警方指控纵火焚烧《古兰经》的男子煽动反对种族或民族群体，并违反了斯德哥尔摩自六月中旬以来实施的禁火令。

虽然瑞典警方拒绝了最近几起反古兰经示威的申请，但法院驳回了这些决定，称它们侵犯了言论自由。

瑞典首相乌尔夫·克里斯特森在周三的新闻发布会上表示，他不会猜测抗议活动将如何影响瑞典的北约进程。

“这是合法的，但不合适，”他说，并补充说，焚烧古兰经的决定取决于警方。

萨尔万·莫米卡（Salwan Momika）是参与其中的两个人之一，他在最近的一次报纸采访中称自己是一名试图禁止《古兰经》的伊拉克难民。

清真寺院长兼伊玛目马哈茂德·哈尔菲周三表示，该清真寺的代表对警方决定批准在穆斯林节日古尔邦节举行抗议活动感到失望。

哈尔菲在一份声明中说：“清真寺建议警方至少将示威活动转移到另一个地点，这在法律上是可能的，但他们选择不这样做。”

据哈尔菲称，每年有多达 10,000 名游客前往斯德哥尔摩清真寺参加开斋节庆祝活动。

一月下旬，一名丹麦极右翼政客在土耳其驻斯德哥尔摩大使馆附近焚烧了一本《古兰经》，土耳其暂停了与瑞典就其北约申请进行的谈判。

  • 17岁少年在巴黎郊区被枪杀
  • 检察官展开凶杀案调查
  • 冲突中31人被捕、40辆汽车被烧毁

周三，法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙(Emmanuel Macron)称一名17岁青少年在巴黎附近的一个交通站点被警察枪杀的事件“不可原谅”，在该事件引发骚乱数小时后，他对执法人员提出了罕见的批评。

一名警察因枪杀这名北非裔年轻人而被指控故意杀人罪，目前正在接受调查。检察官称，他未能遵守周一早些时候停车的命令。

至少 31 人在夜间冲突中被捕，主要发生在受害者居住的巴黎郊区南泰尔，内政部呼吁保持冷静，年轻人焚烧汽车并向警察发射烟花，警察向人们喷洒催泪瓦斯。

马克龙在马赛对记者说：“我们有一名青少年被杀，这是无法解释和不可原谅的。”

“没有任何理由可以证明一个年轻人的死亡是正当的，”他说，然后呼吁司法部门开展工作。

人权组织指控法国执法机构内部存在系统性种族主义，马克龙此前否认了这一指控。

经路透社证实，社交媒体上分享的一段视频显示，这辆奔驰 AMG 车旁边有两名警察，其中一名警察在汽车开走时向司机开枪。当地检察官称，他随后因伤重死亡。

“视频非常清晰：一名警察杀死了一名 17 岁的年轻人。我们可以看到枪击事件不符合规定，”该家庭的律师亚辛·布兹鲁 (Yassine Bouzrou) 说。

议员们在国民议会默哀一分钟，总理伊丽莎白·博恩表示，枪击事件“显然不符合规定”。

律师说，家人已对警官提出杀人、共谋杀人和虚假证言的法律申诉。

在 TikTok 上分享的一段视频中，一名被确认为受害者母亲的妇女周四呼吁在南泰尔举行纪念游行。 “大家都来，我们将为我的儿子领导一场叛乱，”她说。

异常坦率

法国国家警察发言人表示，周二的枪击事件是 2023 年迄今为止法国交通堵塞期间发生的第三起致命枪击事件，低于去年创纪录的 13 起。

据路透社统计，2021 年发生了三起此类杀戮事件，2020 年发生了两起，这表明自 2017 年以来大多数受害者是黑人或阿拉伯裔。

法国人权监察员已对这起死亡事件展开调查，这是 2022 年和 2023 年对类似事件进行的第六次调查。

考虑到选民的安全担忧，高级政客往往不愿批评警察，马克龙的言论异常坦率。

他面临着竞争对手的批评，他们指责他对毒贩和小罪犯态度软弱，并实施了旨在遏制城市犯罪的政策，包括赋予警察更大的罚款权力。

夜间骚乱发生后，内政部表示，巴黎地区已出动 2000 名警察。

周三早上，楠泰尔的街道很平静，居民法蒂玛表示，她希望不再发生暴力事件。

“像我们昨天那样反抗不会改变事情，我们需要讨论和交谈，”她说。

Layli Foroudi、Dominique Vidalon 和 Juliette Jabkhiro 报道；理查德·洛夫 (Richard Lough) 的补充报道；康纳·汉弗莱斯编辑; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 14:42:15 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/youths-clash-with-police-near-paris-after-teenager-shot-dead-traffic-stop-2023-06-28/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/youths-clash-with-police-near-paris-after-teenager-shot-dead-traffic-stop-2023-06-28/Layli Foroudi, Juliette Jabkhiro法国安全/拍摄（更新 3、PIX、电视） Exclusive: Top manager at U.S. firm privately sold high-tech in Russia

美国科技公司极进网络公司去年表示，已暂停在俄罗斯的所有商业活动，以声援“遭受攻击”的乌克兰人民。

但路透社发现，尽管这家美国上市公司正在逐步解除其在俄罗斯的业务，但其在该地区的最高高级管理人员并没有停止在那里开展业务。

根据对两名知情人士的采访，谢尔盖·古萨科夫 (Sergey Gusakov) 仍在担任 Extreme 公司前苏联加盟共和国的经理，并于 2022 年 4 月创建了自己的公司，向俄罗斯客户提供由其雇主的竞争对手制造的 IT 设备。俄罗斯公司和海关记录。

据知情人士和路透社看到的照片称，古萨科夫的公司 Vektor-T 在俄罗斯销售的 IT 设备是在中国组装的，并包含美国微处理器。

结果是：禁止向俄罗斯销售其产品的美国芯片公司生产的微处理器（如 Extreme 所做的那样）已嵌入到中国设备中，这说明了美国贸易限制的局限性。

路透社去年年底的一项调查显示，莫斯科于 2022 年 2 月对乌克兰发动全面入侵后，科技公司自愿实施出口禁令，并采取更广泛的西方制裁，但并未阻止价值数十亿美元的计算机和其他电子元件通过俄罗斯流入俄罗斯。第三方供应商网络。

路透社就他的私人生意联系古萨科夫时，他说：“这是虚构的。再见。”

尽管一名同事在 2022 年夏天向 Extreme 高层发出警告，称他参与向俄罗斯销售技术可能违反公司规定，但古萨科夫已经经营他的平行企业一年多了。

诉状称：“在乌克兰战争的背景下，这些违规行为将导致Extreme公司的声誉受到严重打击。”

当被问及古萨科夫的副业活动时，Extreme发言人告诉路透社，此事正在接受公司法律部门和外部顾问的调查。

他们拒绝对 Vektor-T 的运营发表评论，称这超出了 Extreme 的控制范围，并且没有回答有关 Gusakov 目前在该公司的状况的问题。

发言人表示，Extreme“非常认真地履行遵守美国出口管制的义务”，并且在俄罗斯没有业务。

去年，路透社披露了 Extreme 在入侵乌克兰之前如何向一家美国制裁的军事公司提供 IT 设备，该公司为俄罗斯最先进的武器之一 S-400 防空系统生产导弹。

10月，Extreme证实了路透社的调查结果，称其产品已流向“不良行为者”，并告诉美国监管机构，它将调查现任和前任员工是否可能参与其中，并实施“一流”的出口管制。

许多经销商

据两位知情人士透露，去年 4 月，Extreme 重组了地区办事处，将古萨科夫和部分莫斯科员工迁至哈萨克斯坦。根据该公司网站上发布的简介，古萨科夫于 2010 年加入 Extreme，并保留了独联体地区经理的头衔，独联体是一个前苏联加盟共和国。

但俄罗斯公司记录显示，2022 年 4 月 13 日，古萨科夫在俄罗斯奥廖尔市与他人共同创立了 OOO Vektor-T。据知情人士透露，他没有通知 Extreme。

Vektor-T 在三周前注册的网站上表示，该公司为俄罗斯市场开发和生产一系列计算机网络设备。根据一份法律文件，该公司去年的收入约为 100 万美元。

据两位知情人士透露，Vektor-T 销售的产品由云科中国信息技术有限公司在中国制造，该公司以其 DCN 品牌而闻名。路透社获得的 DCN 和 Vektor-T 品牌销售的交换机内部照片显示，它们是相同的。

Gusakov和Vektor-T没有回应有关DCN技术使用的问题。 DCN 证实向俄罗斯出口产品，但拒绝就其与 Vektor-T 的业务关系发表评论。

俄罗斯海关记录显示，截至 3 月 31 日的 12 个月内，DCN 向俄罗斯出口了价值至少 1100 万美元的设备，其中包括运往 Vektor-T 的货物。

据两位知情人士透露，DCN 产品包含由位于特拉华州威尔明顿的 Marvell Technology Inc. 和位于俄勒冈州希尔斯伯勒的 Lattice Semiconductor Corp 生产的美国微处理器。路透社获得的 DCN 和 Vektor-T 销售的交换机内部照片清楚地显示了其中的一个。

DCN 的一位高级管理人员告诉路透社，该公司的部分产品依赖 Marvell 的半导体，并称这家美国公司“在中国有很多经销商”。关于莱迪思，这位高管首先表示 DCN 使用他们的计算机芯片，但后来又收回说法，称该公司不使用它们。 “DCN产品的美国技术比例很小，”他说。

DCN 高管拒绝就这家中国公司是否获得 Marvell 和 Lattice 向俄罗斯出口其产品的授权发表评论。

Marvell 通过电子邮件向路透社表示，该公司不会向俄罗斯销售产品，并且其在中国的所有分销商及其客户必须证明其产品不会转售给俄罗斯。公司发言人表示，Marvell 已有 10 年没有直接向 DCN 发货，但补充说，它无法始终跟踪其产品的最终去向。

该发言人表示：“某些分销商的客户可能会进一步将产品转售给 Marvell 或其分销商不了解、不了解或无法控制的公司。”

莱迪思告诉路透社，当乌克兰遭到入侵时，该公司停止了对俄罗斯的所有销售，并完全遵守美国的出口法规。该公司没有回答路透社关于 DCN 是否是客户的问题。

白俄罗斯总统亚历山大·卢卡申科表示，他说服俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京不要“消灭”雇佣军首领叶夫根尼·普里戈任，以回应克里姆林宫所说的将俄罗斯推向内战的叛变。

普京最初发誓要镇压这次叛变，并将其与引发 1917 年革命和随后内战的战时动乱相比较，但几小时后达成协议，允许普里戈任和他的一些战士前往白俄罗斯。

普里戈任周二从俄罗斯飞往白俄罗斯。

在描述他周六与普京的谈话时，卢卡申科使用了俄罗斯犯罪俚语来表示杀人，相当于英语中的“消灭”。

据白俄罗斯官方媒体报道，卢卡申科周二在军队官员和记者会议上表示，“我也明白：已经做出了残酷的决定（这是普京讲话的基调），以消灭”叛乱分子。

“我建议普京不要着急。‘来吧，’我说，‘让我们和普里戈任以及他的指挥官谈谈。’他告诉我：‘听着，萨沙，这是没有用的。他甚至不接电话，他不想和任何人说话’。”

1999年，普京在谈到车臣武装分子时也使用了同样的俄语动词，并发誓要“在茅屋里消灭他们”，这句话后来成为他严厉性格的广泛引用的象征。

克里姆林宫没有立即对卢卡申科的言论发表评论，根据普京自己的说法，卢卡申科的言论让人们对克里姆林宫内部的对话有了罕见的了解，因为根据普京自己的说法，俄罗斯正在走向几十年来从未见过的动荡。

卢卡申科既是普里戈任的老熟人，也是普京的亲密盟友，他表示，他曾建议俄罗斯总统“超越我们自己的鼻子”思考，普里戈任的下台可能会导致他的战士们广泛反抗。

这位白俄罗斯领导人还表示，他自己的军队可以从瓦格纳部队的经验中受益，根据与克里姆林宫达成的协议，瓦格纳部队现在可以自由前往白俄罗斯。

白通社国家通讯社援引卢卡申科的话说：“这是军队中训练有素的部队。” “谁会反对这一点？我的军队也明白这一点，而我们白俄罗斯没有这样的人。”

后来卢卡申科告诉他的军队，“人们不明白我们正在以务实的方式解决这个问题……他们（瓦格纳）经历过这一切，他们会告诉我们有关武器的信息——哪些有效，哪些无效。 ”

根据卢卡申科和普京的说法，他在结束一场威胁到世界最大核国家稳定的叛乱中发挥了重要作用。

在卢卡申科的讲述中——他周二做了一些细节——他是在电话谈判中说服流氓雇佣军领导人叶夫根尼·普里戈任停止叛变的人，也是建议普京不要“消灭”普里戈任的人。

卢卡申科说：“......已经做出了消灭叛乱分子的残酷决定。我建议普京不要着急。”

卢卡申科依靠莫斯科提供廉价能源来维持该国苏联式的经济，并依靠莫斯科的安全机构来确保自己在极端情况下的政治生存，目前尚不清楚莫斯科还能给他带来什么。

但他至少为自己赢得了更多的政治善意，在适当的时候他可以将其转化为进一步的金融和经济让步。

在国内，卢卡申科长期以来一直将这个夹在北约和俄罗斯之间的具有重要战略意义的国家视为莫斯科年轻但坚定忠诚的兄弟，他也被称赞为莫斯科的救世主——尽管这是受到他自己严格控制的媒体的称赞。

在一个戏剧性的周末，尘埃仍在尘埃落定，这挑战了许多人对俄罗斯内部政治和稳定的假设。

然而，卢卡申科干预的一个直接后果是显而易见的：引发兵变、几个月来一直是俄罗斯国防部眼中钉的普里戈任现在流亡在白俄罗斯。

数以千计的战士可能会追随他。

卢卡申科周二表示，白俄罗斯无需担心雇佣兵的存在，他们可以与他的军队分享战场经验。 “我们将密切关注他们，”他说。

安德鲁·奥斯本报道；迈克·科莱特-怀特和亚历克斯·理查森编辑; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 12:53:43 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/belarus-leader-long-supplicant-feted-Russia-after-mutiny-role-2023-06-27/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/belarus-leader-long-supplicant-feted-Russia-after-mutiny-role-2023-06-27/Andrew Osborn乌克兰危机/俄罗斯卢卡申科（更新 1、分析、PIX） Catalonia cracks down on booming marijuana industrySummary:
  • 西班牙地区是欧洲顶级生产国之一
  • 西班牙缉获的大麻占欧盟大麻缉获量的 66%
  • 西班牙有关大麻的法律灰色地带
  • 巴塞罗那新市长领导下吸烟俱乐部面临不确定性

全副武装的警察在黎明前抵达巴塞罗那一个富裕的郊区，突袭了一栋两层楼的房子，结果发现里面长满了 800 棵在强光灯下生长的大麻植物。

最近，路透社陪同警察逮捕了两名阿尔巴尼亚国民，这次突袭是西班牙加泰罗尼亚地区警方几乎日常例行行动的一部分，该地区旨在打击蓬勃发展的非法大麻生产，这些大麻生产通常由当地和国际毒品经营。帮派。

要了解有关此故事的更多信息，请点击今天的路透社世界新闻集。

近年来，主要是美洲的一些国家将大麻使用合法化或监管，西班牙在法律上允许个人消费，而巴塞罗那本身主办了欧洲最大的大麻主题博览会，这样的压制似乎有悖常理。

但警方认为，围绕大麻生意不断增长的有组织犯罪正在使该地区的部分地区成为危险的地方，需要予以打击，以防止犯罪团伙进一步根深蒂固。

他们表示，他们的目标通常不是小规模种植者或使用者，他们经常光顾存在法律漏洞的所谓大麻俱乐部，而是由将大部分大麻出口到国外的盈利驱动的贩毒团伙。

加泰罗尼亚警察有组织犯罪部门负责人安东尼·萨勒拉斯 (Antoni Salleras) 表示：“当这是一项能产生如此多金钱的生意时，犯罪组织就会集中来到这里。”他指出，外国人（主要来自欧洲其他地方、摩洛哥和拉丁美洲）占了大约去年逮捕人数的 60%。

萨勒拉斯说，一些房地产或运输服务现在几乎完全为生产商提供服务，而贩毒团伙之间为了保护种植园而“暴力程度上升”，引发了非法持有枪支的“令人担忧”的增加。

去年，加泰罗尼亚警方查获了 26 吨大麻芽，是 2021 年的三倍，并逮捕了 2,130 人，该地区因宽松的法律、气候和其他因素而成为欧洲主要种植区之一。

警方表示，在加泰罗尼亚，大麻的价值约为 1.56 亿欧元（1.71 亿美元），一克大麻的售价高达 6 欧元，而在欧洲其他地方，该重量的大麻将以两倍至四倍的价格出售。

在巴塞罗那，大麻及其高效衍生物的消费也在蓬勃发展，包括在私人俱乐部。

根据欧盟药品机构 EMCDDA 的一项研究，2022 年，巴塞罗那废水中的大麻含量在数十个欧洲城市中排名第三，仅次于日内瓦和阿姆斯特丹，但低于 2021 年巴塞罗那排名第一的水平。

EMCDDA 表示，大麻（用于所有从该植物中提取的产品的术语）是欧洲最常消费的药物，也是与整个欧盟违反毒品法最相关的药物。 2021 年缉获量达到十年来的最高水平，其中西班牙占总量的 66%。

EMCDDA Director Alexis Goosdeel told Reuters that illegally-grown cannabis has increased in areas with a climate conducive to large-scale production like Catalonia, a trend that "worries all EU member states".

Private clubs, where buying and smoking marijuana is allowed thanks to legal loopholes and the absence of national regulation, have grown in number to around an estimated 600 in Catalonia, or nearly half of Spain's 1,500 estimated total.

Their model, however, faces uncertainty as the new Barcelona mayor's top security official said in March he wanted to ban cannabis clubs.

The mayor's office declined to comment.

FRENCH CONNECTION

Catalonia used to be a transit area for marijuana until production started around eight years ago and has soared since, said the police chief. It is now Spain's top producing region, with most exports channelled by road to France.

Salleras said Catalonia is attractive because producers can use properties left empty after the bursting of Spain's property bubble in 2008, the process to evict them is lengthy, theft of electricity does not carry a jail sentence, and marijuana-related crimes carry lighter sentences than in neighbouring countries.

It is illegal to produce marijuana in Spain, but cultivating it for personal use or smoking it is not punishable if both occur in a private space because it is protected by privacy rights, said specialist lawyer Bernardo Soriano.

Buying seeds is tolerated under the premise that it is for collection purposes, while cannabis clubs are permitted by the constitutional right to association and the lack of a widespread judicial doctrine, although carrying marijuana is illegal.

In 2017, Catalonia fully legalised the clubs, fuelling their proliferation, but courts later overturned the move for procedural reasons.

Under self-imposed rules, clubs should grow their own marijuana, only let in adults who can buy up to 60 grams monthly and take 15 days to approve memberships to put off short-term tourists.

But many clubs, which are often barely recognisable from outside, do not stick to the rules because they are voluntary, complained Eric Asensio, head of the Catalan federation of cannabis clubs.

"We believe the lack of (legal) control is causing many problems."

Before Hollywood writers walked off the job in early May, Pam Elyea's prop house History for Hire filled an average of 53 requests per week for everything from period-appropriate cameras and luggage to camping gear and snow globes.

Weekly orders this year now average 26 as the strike by the Writers Guild of America (WGA) halted many film and TV productions, Elyea said. She estimates the revenue of the company, which she runs with her husband, has dropped 60% and it is falling $100,000 short of meeting monthly expenses.

"Even though there is a strike going on, it doesn't stop my staff's rent. It certainly doesn't stop my rent. It doesn't stop our utilities," Elyea said, adding "things are just so much more expensive since the pandemic."

Small businesses in Los Angeles and beyond are taking a hit from the strike. Florists, caterers, costume suppliers and others have seen orders dwindle as many are still recovering from disruptions caused by COVID-19.

It is unclear how long the work stoppage will last. No new talks are scheduled between major Hollywood studios and the writers, who are seeking higher pay and guardrails around the use of artificial intelligence .

The strike's impact would be magnified if the SAG-AFTRA actors union also goes on strike when its contract expires on Friday.

One rough measure of the current toll is the number of permits issued for movie and TV filming in Los Angeles. That number has fallen 56% from a year ago, according to permitting organization FilmLA.

Typically, dozens of scripted television projects would be in production for the fall broadcast season. As of June 18, there were just three with permits to film in the city.

Economists say it is too early to measure the full economic toll.

But the 100-day WGA strike in 2007-08 resulted in the loss of 37,700 jobs in California and cost the state $2.1 billion in lost output, according to Kevin Klowden, chief global strategist for the Milken Institute. It took months for the impact to become clear, as restaurants, logistics companies and cleaning services cut staff.

That work stoppage tipped the state into the Great Recession of 2007 through 2009, and California took longer than the rest of the United States to rebound, Klowden said.

"It took a year for schedules to recover, for workers to recover," said Klowden.

This time, businesses may be more vulnerable.

"You've got people who have barely recovered from COVID," said Ross Garner, managing director in NFP's Entertainment Group, an insurance broker for rental houses and production and audio/visual companies. "They really don't have the reserves that they had four years ago, pre-COVID, to help them survive this potentially extended period."

Most of NFP's clients have laid off at least 35% of their staffs. One that rents sound stages cut its workforce by half, laying off custodians, stage managers and others.

CUTTING BACK INVENTORY

Sassy Craft Services, which provides food and drink to sets, used to book about eight jobs per month with productions for companies including Netflix (NFLX.O) and HBO (WBD.O) , said owner Danni Sapp.

That has dropped to about three, Sapp said. She helps fill the gap with smaller jobs such as providing coffee for a store opening.

Sapp is now considering diversifying her income sources by becoming a pilates instructor.

"It's something I always wanted to do and now I have time for that, which is very different because normally I'm super busy," she said.

Some assistance is available.加州的工作共享计划旨在帮助公司避免裁员。 An employer can reduce a worker's hours to four days a week, for example, and ask the state to temporarily cover the fifth.

Nonprofits also are helping.为娱乐行业工人提供援助的电影电视基金会表示，从 5 月到 6 月第三周，已收到近 1,000 份与罢工相关的援助请求。 That is three times the normal number.

The strike is rippling to states such as New Mexico that have become popular filming locations.

The vintage Western clothing shop Kowboyz is a tourist destination in Santa Fe, earning a mention in Vogue magazine for its "rodeo-ready" apparel.

Owners Cristina and John Iverson said movies and television shows account for 10 to 15% of its revenue. It provided wardrobe for the series "Outer Range" and the "Waco" miniseries, where the costume designer memorably purchased 150 pairs of cowboy boots to outfit the show's FBI agents.

Actors and crew often shop in the store when they are not on set, providing more income.

"We are on the film industry's list of resources," said Cristina Iverson. "We're on their radar."

As productions in Santa Fe dried up during the strike, the owners tightened spending.约翰·艾弗森表示，自疫情爆发以来，该店一直无法完全补充库存。 Iverson estimates Kowboyz's selection of cowboy boots is down to about 1,500 pairs, or about half its typical stock.

"It's been very hard for us to bring back what we used to have," said Cristina Iverson, noting the difficulty of re-establishing a supply chain of pickers who rummage flea markets for used and vintage items. "Now, there's the writers' strike, and we're losing the movies that have been so good to us."

History for Hire also has curbed purchases, Elyea said, and had to turn down a striking writer who called with the hope of earning some cash by selling her 1990s electronics.

"You're the reason I can't buy from you," Elyea said she told the writer. "She hadn't made the correlation that her actions had a repercussion in the community. We're all inter-related."

Reporting by Lisa Richwine and Dawn Chmielewski; Additional reporting by Danielle Broadway and Rollo Ross; Editing by Mary Milliken and Sandra Maler ; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 10:28:51 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/us/caterers-cowboy-outfitters-writers-strike-hits-hollywood-economy-2023-06-28/ https://www.reuters.com/world/us/caterers-cowboy-outfitters-writers-strike-hits-hollywood-economy-2023-06-28/Lisa Richwine, Dawn Chmielewski TELEVISION WRITERS/ECONOMY (PIX, TV) Most Americans support US arming Ukraine, Reuters/Ipsos poll shows

Solid majorities of Americans support providing weaponry to Ukraine to defend itself against Russia and believe that such aid demonstrates to China and other US rivals a will to protect US interests and allies, according to a Reuters/Ipsos survey.

The two-day poll that was concluded on Tuesday charted a sharp rise in backing for arming Ukraine, with 65% of the respondents approving of the shipments compared with 46% in a May poll.

Eighty-one percent of Democrats, 56% of Republicans and 57% of independents favor supplying US weapons to Ukraine, according to the latest poll.

The survey was conducted just days after Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the private Wagner mercenary company, launched and then called off a mutiny over what he charged was the Russian defense ministry's mishandling of the war in Ukraine.

The findings appeared to provide firmer backing for US President Joe Biden's policy of doing "whatever it takes" to assist Ukraine in recapturing territory that Russia seized in an initial assault in 2014 and its full-scale invasion 16 months ago.

"This definitely reinforces Biden's decision to be all-in on this," said William Taylor, a former US ambassador to Ukraine now with the US Institute of Peace.

"The Republican leadership of the House and Senate will also take heart from this," Taylor said. Some right-wing Republican lawmakers have opposed continuing US military support for Ukraine.

The Biden administration has approved 41 weapons packages for Ukraine totaling more than $40 billion since Russian President Vladimir Putin launched what he calls "a special military operation" in February 2022.

The online Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted nationwide, collecting responses from 1,004 adults, including 400 Democrats and 383 Republicans. It had a credibility interval, a measure of precision, of about 4 percentage points in either direction.

The poll found that 76% of Americans believe that providing aid to Ukraine demonstrates to China and other rivals that the United States has "the will and capability to protect our interests, our allies and ourselves."

In other findings, the survey said large majorities of Americans - 67% and 73% - are more likely to support a candidate in next year's US presidential election who will continue military aid to Ukraine and one who backs the NATO alliance.

Reporting by Jonathan Landay; Additional reporting by Jason Lange; Editing by Don Durfee and Grant McCool ; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 10:04:59 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/most-americans-support-us-arming-ukraine-reutersipsos-2023-06-28/ https://www.reuters.com/world/most-americans-support-us-arming-ukraine-reutersipsos-2023-06-28/Jonathan Landay乌克兰CRISIS/POLL (POLL, PIX) Cheap Russian drone a menace to Ukrainian troops and equipment

As Russia's invasion enters its 17th month, Ukrainian forces say Moscow is ramping up its use of low-cost suicide drones that are capable of destroying equipment many times their value and not easy to defend against.

The Lancet drone, an angular grey tube with two sets of four wings, has been an increasing threat on Ukraine's frontlines in recent months, according to Ukrainian solders.

Videos posted by pro-Russian social media channels over the last month appear to show Lancet drones damaging or destroying Ukraine's valuable Western-donated equipment, such as a Leopard 2 tank and a Caesar self-propelled howitzer.

Ukrainian servicemen from four different artillery crews named Lancets as one of the main threats they faced on the battlefield in conversations with Reuters.

Several soldiers said the frequency of its use had increased in recent months.

"Earlier, in spring, they were not using Lancets as often as they are now," 35-year-old artillery gunner Bohdan, who gave his call sign as Doc, told Reuters near Avdiivka on the Donetsk region frontlines.

Russia's defence ministry has been encouraging an increase of production of the Lancet as a cheap way to hit high-value western equipment given to Ukraine for its counteroffensive, said Samuel Bendett, Adjunct Senior Fellow at the Center for a New American Security.

Bendett said that, according to publicly available Russian sources, a Lancet drone costs approximately 3 million roubles (around $35,000).

In comparison, analysts estimate a single S-300 missile used by Russia to cost at least several hundred thousand dollars. A Leopard 2 tank is worth several million dollars.

Because the Lancet is a single-use device that destroys itself on impact, Bendett said it can only be viable if the cost is kept down to the tens of thousands of dollars per drone.

DRONE WARS

Ukraine has also developed strong capabilities in drones - also known as UAVs (unmanned aerial vehicles) - as a cost-effective way to hit Russian targets.

Assault drones can send payloads to hit their target or serve as single-use "loitering munitions" - where they are strapped with explosives and ram the target themselves.

Bendett said there was unhappiness among pro-war Russian commentators about the large amount of Ukrainian videos showing successful UAV strikes, and that the Russian defence sector now wanted to create a competing narrative.

Russia appears to be copying some of Ukraine's earlier tactics, such as luring high-value targets forward into more exposed positions before hitting them with loitering munitions, Bendett said.

Yuriy Sak, an adviser to Ukraine's defence minister, acknowledged that Russia's increasing use of Lancets created difficulties.

"Every day we shoot down at least one or two of these Lancets ... but it's not a 100% interception rate unfortunately," he said.

Sak said the Lancet carried a relatively small explosive payload, ranging from 1.5-5 kg.

However, despite being less powerful than an artillery shell or most rockets, the Lancet appears to be able to inflict significant damage.

Lancet drones are flown in real-time by a pilot.

Sak said this distinguishes it from the Iran-made Shahed-136 drone, which Russia has also used extensively to hit Ukrainian targets, because a Shahed flies to a pre-programmed destination and cannot be piloted while in the air.

A NEAR MISS

The newest Lancet model, the Lancet 3, can fly up to 50 km (30 miles), Bendett said, making it better able to strike targets deep behind Ukrainian lines than any other Russian suicide drone besides the Shahed.

Its ability to loiter and then chase down its target makes it a threat to high-value equipment such as tanks, self-propelled artillery and rocket launch systems.

One of the Ukrainian vehicles most at risk is the BM-21 Grad, a large Soviet-era truck-mounted launcher that can fire a barrage of up to 40 rockets over a wide area.

Its firepower makes it a priority target for Lancet drones, and a video shared by pro-war Russian social media channels last week appeared to show a Grad being hit by a Lancet. Reuters could not independently verify the footage.

A crew member of a Grad launcher near Avdiivka, who introduced himself by his call sign Voron, recounted having a close brush with a Lancet which had been sent to attack his launcher in early May.

Having fired on a Russian target, Voron said his Grad was immediately targeted by a Russian S-300 missile, which missed by about 150 metres. However, a Lancet drone then appeared in the sky and chased the Ukrainian rocket system.

"We decided to flee ... After about 50 metres it fell just to my right. It didn't hit us, thank God," the 27-year-old said.

Drones like the Lancet, which fly low and slow, tend to confuse traditional air defence systems, which are built to intercept fast-moving targets with a larger heat signature.

Nets or metal cages can help limit the damage, said Sak, the defence ministry official, but the best defences are radar-equipped automated anti-drone guns, as well as electronic warfare systems.

Sak said Ukraine needed many more of these systems from its allies.

Without such systems, Ukrainian soldiers are often forced to try to shoot the Lancets down with small arms.

"It's flying at 100 kilometres per hour, so shooting it down with small arms is not an easy challenge," said Sak.

British-born actor Julian Sands, best known for his role in the Oscar-celebrated film "A Room with a View," was confirmed dead on Tuesday, five months after he went missing while out for a hike in snow-covered mountains of Southern California. He was 65.

Mostly skeletal human remains discovered by hikers on June 25, in the vicinity where Sands had vanished, were positively identified by the San Bernardino County coroner as belonging to the actor, the county sheriff's department said.

The manner of his death remained under investigation, awaiting further test results, the department said in an statement.

Sands, an avid outdoorsman and mountaineer, was reported missing on Jan. 13, after he had gone hiking alone earlier in the day in the Baldy Bowl area of the San Gabriel Mountains, about 50 miles (80 km) northeast of Los Angeles.

The large, slopping area below the crest of Mount Baldy is a popular destination for skiers, climbers and backpackers. But authorities warned then that heavy snow from weeks of winter storms had made the area treacherous for outdoor recreation. Overnight temperatures were dipping into the mid-20s Fahrenheit (4 to minus 4 Celsius) that week.

A search party organized at the time was pulled out 24 hours later due to avalanche risks and poor trail conditions. Several subsequent searches came up empty-handed, including a major sweep conducted days before Sands' remains were ultimately found in the Mount Baldy wilderness area, according to the sheriff's department.

Cellphone signals detected on Sunday, Jan. 15, had showed Sands headed toward the ridge of Mount Baldy, apparently the last indication he was still on the move, the sheriff's department reported then.

A statement from Sands' family posted by the sheriff's department on June 21, after the agency's latest search but before his remains were found, thanked search teams for their efforts and sounded a note of resignation about his fate.

"We continue to hold Julian in our hearts with bright memories of him as a wonderful father, husband, explorer, love of the natural world and the arts, and as an original and collaborative performer," the statement said.

Sands, in a 2020 interview with the Guardian newspaper, described himself as happiest when he was "close to a mountain summit on a glorious cold morning." He also recalled a brush with death during a climb in the Andes in the early 1990s when he became caught in a storm above 20,000 feet (6,000 meters) with three others.

"We were all in a very bad way," he recounted. "Some guys close to us perished. We were lucky."

ROMANCE AND HORROR

Born in England as the third of five boys and educated at Lord Wandsworth College in Hampshire, Sands began his career with supporting roles in such films as "Oxford Blues," appearing as the romantic rival of Rob Lowe's lead character, and "The Killing Fields," playing a young war correspondent in Cambodia.

Sands moved to California in the 1980s after the success of "A Room with a View," an Edwardian-period romance in which he was cast as the leading man opposite Helena Bonham Carter.

Based on EM Forster's 1908 novel of the same title and set in England and Italy, the 1985 film was nominated for eight Academy Awards, including best picture. It won Oscars for best adapted screenplay, art direction and costume design.

Developing a knack for the horror genre, Sands also starred as a son of Satan in the 1989 supernatural thriller "Warlock" and its sequel "Warlock: The Armageddon." He played a spider expert in the 1990 comedy-creeper "Arachnophobia," a twisted, obsessed surgeon in 1993's "Boxing Helena" and the title role in the 1998 film version of "The Phantom of the Opera."

Other movies included "Leaving Las Vegas," "Naked Lunch" and the English-language remake of "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo." He also appeared in more than two dozen television shows, among them "Smallville" as Superman's biological dad Jor-El.

In recent years, Sands found success appearing in one-man stage shows reciting the poetry of Harold Pinter, John Keats and Percy Shelley, the latter of which he played in the 1986 psychological thriller "Gothic."

Although never Oscar-nominated himself, Sands dated Jodie Foster and was her escort to the Academy Awards in 1989 the night she won her first best-actress statuette for "The Accused." The two co-starred in the little-seen 1987 indie film "Siesta."

But the outdoors, and mountain climbing in particular, remained a lifelong obsession.

As quoted in a 2020 interview with Thrive Global, a company founded by Arianna Huffington, Sands said climbing was not about ego or a "great heroic sprint for the summit" but rather "about supplication and sacrifice and humility."

"It's not so much a celebration of oneself but the eradication of one's self consciousness. And so on these walks you lose yourself, you become a vessel of energy in harmony hopefully with your environment."

He is survived by his second wife, Evgenia Citkowitz, a journalist, with whom he had two daughters. He also had a son by his first wife, journalist Sarah Harvey.
